units.description: A creative spark or innovative idea is not enough to succeed as a start-up organisation. A new idea behind a product or a service needs to be first verified to understand the business opportunities out there. Then the identified opportunities need to be adjusted to formalise in a business concept. This unit aims to guide students through that process of converting the creative or innovative idea into the development of a product or service as a sound business concept. This objective is driven through teams of students advancing with their practical projects and along the way learning about a number of theoretical topics such as:  prototyping, user testing, etc. The unit will be delivered through a number of modules. As a vital part of the unit, students are expected to engage and work in “start-up co-working space” on a regular basis. At the successful completion of this unit, students would have converted the innovative idea into a business product or service.
units.approachToLearning:
The unit builds knowledge and understanding around the stages of New Product Development, from idea generation to test marketing. The students will have an opportunity to apply practical concepts and techniques involved in new product planning, development, implementation and control. Besides learning about theory and practice of entrepreneurs, students will engage in active learning by working in cross-functional teams to develop an initial prototype of their product idea.

The unit specifically focuses on the following - 
-	Interplay between product, service and system aspects of product design
-	Developing the product prototype utilising technological skills 
-	Testing and refinement of a product 
-	Creative problem-solving in product development 
-	Marketing material development that promotes the product

Further, three key components are designed to support the students:
-	Face to face contact: weekly four-hour face to face lecture and tutorial per week
-	Online: modules provided via vUWS site
-	Students Working on the prototype

Students will work on developing their prototypes in the computer labs during the tutorials. The unit’s content provides students with an understanding of the cross-functional activities required to take an idea from the initial planning phase through to early prototyping phase. This unit effectively provides a full introduction to a New Product Development within a startup, however, in practice it is expected that students may only be able to produce an initial prototype.

Unit content includes, but is not limited to:
-	Product planning 
-	Development processes
-	Innovation tools
-	Product specifications
-	Concept generation, selection and testing
-	Product architecture
-	Robust design
-	Prototyping
-	Generating marketing material for product promotion using principles and practices of the innovation process.
units.name: Incubator 3: Product Development
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Follow through the steps associated with product development.
2. Test the product for any issues.
3. Resolve any product issues by applying iterative development approach.
4. Develop initial marketing material for product promotion.
5. Apply individual’s skills and knowledge in a collaborative and effective manner in achieving a common goal in a group setting.
6. Demonstrate effective verbal and written communication skills that appeal to a wide audience.
units.passCriteria:
There are three assessment components in this unit, designed to enable you to demonstrate that you have achieved the unit learning outcomes. Completion and submission of all assessment items which have been designated as mandatory or compulsory is essential to receive a passing grade. 

To pass this unit:
- an overall mark of at least 50% is required

units.description: Operating a start-up is not just about being creative and innovative; it is also about having the necessary management and operational skills, understanding the commercial and financial setting within which the organisation needs to operate it. This unit aims to provide vital details that set the background to run your organisation whether your customer base is local, national or even international. This objective is driven through a number of topics such as: setting up a business entity, accounting fundamentals, taxation fundamentals. The unit will be delivered through a number of modules. As a vital part of the unit, students are expected to engage and work in “start-up co-working space" on a regular basis. At the successful completion of this unit, students would set up as a business entity for their start-up organisation.
units.approachToLearning:
The unit provides an authentic and evidence-based learning experience for the study of the commercial and financial settings of entrepreneurship. The learners engage and apply concepts including: planning, strategizing and decision making in commercial and financial contexts that will be useful in developing a start-up. Students will learn about the types of business entities, choosing appropriate business structures, identifying accounting needs, pricing, budgeting, reading financial documents; and understanding different sources of funding and the way in which taxes and government regulations affect the operations of start-ups.

The objective of the course is to provide learners with financial management skills and knowledge that will enable them to successfully make financial decisions and successfully manage business operations. The learners will gain an understanding of financial management and decision-making approaches, allowing them to independently assess the financial position of a business. They will also be able to plan, assess and present financial statements such as a cash flow, profit and loss and balance sheet to evaluate the financial viability of a planned business venture.

The implications of tax legislation are studied including the fundamental tax principles, taxation of individuals, partnerships and companies as well as understanding specific investment and related tax structures relevant to start-ups. 

The unit also provides an overview of marketing processes to familiarise students with fundamental concepts of marketing including research and validation. The unit introduces the learners to the process of conducting effective marketing research, and includes research techniques such as research design, value and cost of information, use of secondary and primary data, data processing and analysis and report presentation. This unit will specifically focus on entrepreneurial marketing in business to business and business to consumer contexts. 

Content includes, but is not limited to:
•	Setting up a business entity in Australia
•	Business regulations when starting up
•	Choosing and registering a business name
•	Setting up and managing business accounts
•	Understanding business accounting; understanding the role of a bank
•	Drawing up a budget; controlling a budget; controlling costs
•	Taxation structures and how they affects start-ups
•	Market validation
•	Conducting market research
•	Sources of funding & relationship to tax structures
•	Start-up ownership and equity sharing
•	Pricing strategies
•	Communicating new business ideas, plans and innovations in formats that engage and influence diverse stakeholders

Three key components are designed to support the students:
•	Face to face contact: weekly four-hour face to face lecture and tutorial per week
•	Online: modules provided via vUWS site
•	Students Working on the start-up idea remotely or at the launch pad facility
units.name: Incubator 4: Commercial and Financial Setting of Entrepreneurship
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Identify and apply the process involved in setting up a business entity.
2. Identify business accounting needs and chose appropriate accounting structure.
3. Investigate how the Australian and international taxation structures applies to start-ups.
4. Demonstrate an understanding of interpreting accounting documents that are commonly used in a business setting.
5. Apply individual’s skills and knowledge in a collaborative and effective manner in achieving a common goal in a group setting.
6. Demonstrate effective verbal and written communication skills that appeal to a wide audience.

units.description: Planning is an important part of setting up a start-up business. This would require investigating into setting goals, figuring out how to track progress, what to do when things don't go to plan and also to communicate your business concept to others, such as potential investors. This unit aims to develop the skills and knowledge required for making a business plan for the start-up organisation through a number of theoretical topics, such as: developing marketing and operational plans, staffing and management. At the completion of this unit, students will have developed a viable business plan for their start-up.
units.approachToLearning:
The unit provides an authentic and evidence based learning experience of the study of the operational aspects of entrepreneurship. The unit introduces a novel approach to studying the core concepts in operations, which is one the three major functional fields in start up management, along with finance and marketing. 

Operations Management is concerned with the management of business processes. This units looks at ways in which operations can be managed and improved while examining the real-world operational challenges and execution risks associated with getting a new venture started. The unit introduces principles, analytical frameworks, and tools that can be used to understand the important considerations for building a start up operation from scratch.  The learners engage and learn to apply planning, strategizing and decision making in operational contexts that will be useful in their start ups.

Content includes, but is not limited to:
-	The role of Operations in developing a Business Model for a start up.
-	Resource allocation and Staffing and Management structures  
-	Agile product management
-	Operational Risks and Challenges in launching a start up
-	Operations Metrics for Managing start up performance
-	Operational planning for short term, midterm and long term
-	Iterative, incremental development and continual improvement as applied to start up operations

Three key components are designed to support the students:

•	Face to face contact: weekly four-hour face to face lecture and tutorial per week
•	Online: modules provided via vUWS site
•	Students Working on the start-up idea remotely or at the launch pad facility

This unit effectively provides a full introduction to the operational aspects for start-up businesses – in practice students will only be able to understand and examine operational principles and frameworks at this early stage.
units.name: Incubator 5: Operational Aspects of Entrepreneurship
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Identify the various resource requirements for a start-up operation
2. Apply agile product management
3. Use appropriate examples to demonstrate the cycle of iterative, incremental development and continual improvement
4. Appreciate the human resources (HR) and staffing needs of a start-up operation
5. Develop short-mid-term business plan
6. Apply individual’s skills and knowledge in a collaborative and effective manner to achieve a common goal in a group setting
7. Demonstrate effective verbal and written communication skills that appeal to a wide audience
units.passCriteria:
-	Achieve at least 50% to pass this unit.
-	Note: An overall mark for workshop portfolios (practicals) of at least 50% is required to pass this unit.

There are three assessment components in this unit, designed to enable you to demonstrate that you have achieved the unit learning outcomes. The assessment components are also set up to assist you to develop at least a conceptualisation of a possible new concept or technology or software application and associated startup enterprise. Completion and submission of all assessment items which have been designated as mandatory or compulsory is essential to receive a passing grade. 

Assessments are classified as either Group (G) or Individual (I)
1. Report (I) (30%) - Report (Case Study) Due: Week 6
2. Report (G) (50%) - Team Project Report - Short, Mid and Long term business plan Due: Week 12 
3 Presentation (I) (20%)- Individual Pitch Deck 10%; Individual Pitch Presentation 10% Due: Week 14

units.description: This unit investigates various funding opportunities that might be suitable for your business concept through a number of theoretical topics, such as: possible funding sources including venture capitalists and angel investors, joint venture funding, pitching your ideas. The unit is structured into a number of modules. Further, as activities associated with this unit, students would have to actively seek and secure funding for the start-up.
units.approachToLearning:
The unit provides an authentic and evidence-based learning experience for the study of the funding opportunities in the  settings of startups. The learners engage and apply concepts related to funding options for early stage startups. This unit investigates into various funding opportunities that might suitable for your business concept through a number of theoretical topics, such as: possible funding sources including venture capitalists and angel investors, joint venture funding, pitching your ideas, etc. The unit is structured into a number of modules. 

As a vital part of the unit, students are expected to engage and work in 'start-up co-working space' on a regular basis. Further, as activities associated with this unit, students would have to actively seek and secure funding for the start-up.

A distinctive aspect of this unit is active learning. Throughout the semester students will work with a real start-up that they are in the process of setting up. Students will apply their learning by trying to raise funds and investment, running a crowdfunding campaign and culminating in a pitch to investors. This unit will use a blend of lectures, discussion, cases, readings and experts from both entrepreneurship and funding/investment.

Key questions addressed are –
When to raise outside capital?
What kind of investment, at what stage and ways to find?
How to successfully launch a crowdfunding campaign?
How to run a crowdfunding campaign?
How to pitch to investors?

The course content is divided into five broad sections –
1. The Early Stage Investment Landscape
- understanding the investment landscape
- the language of raising start-up capital
- what financial statements do investors want to see?
- what corporate structure should I use?
- how do investors view your early stage venture?

2. Sources of Capital for the Early Stage Company
- introduction - Sources of capital
- where to find investors?
- why consider friends and family as investors?
- bootstrapping?
- angel investors?
- are you ready to raise capital?

3. Getting Funded – Steps in the Funding Process
- steps in the funding process
- what is due diligence?
- startup valuation - What is your company worth?
- alternative sources of capital

4. Pitching to Investors and Closing the Round
- what investors want
- creating a pitch deck
- telling your story
- do’s and don’ts of pitching
- closing the round 

5. Funding for Gaming Startups

Three key components are designed to support the students:
- Face to face contact: weekly four-hour face to face lecture and tutorial per week
- Online: modules provided via vUWS site
- Students Working on the start-up idea remotely or at the launch pad facility

4. Demonstrate effective verbal and written communication skills that appeal to a wide audience.
5. Demonstrate resilience when faced with probable disappointing rejections from financiers.

units.description: This unit will assist students with selecting the further growth strategy, which includes deciding whether their business would grow organically or will require a fast growth model and rapid expansion strategies. The growth strategy will determine further funding decisions. Apart from this, as entrepreneurs, the students would need to also consider possible exit strategies (e.g. initial public offering (IPO), trade sales or personal redundancies). This objective is driven through a number of topics such as: elements of market research and strategies for business growth, risk management, possible exit strategies, etc. The unit will be delivered through a number of modules. As a tangible outcome, at the completion of this unit, students would have developed a future growth plan with an identification of possible exit strategies.
units.approachToLearning: An important part of a start-up business is having a prior understanding of possible growth options and possible exit strategies. In other words, if a multinational company offers to buy your business for a reasonably attractive price in the current market, should you sell it?   This module will help students with selecting the further growth strategy, which includes deciding whether their business would grow organically or will require a fast growth model and rapid expansion strategies. The growth strategy will determine further funding decisions. Apart from this, as entrepreneurs, the students would need to also consider possible exit strategies (e.g. IPO, trade sales or personal redundancies). This objective is driven through a number of topics such as: elements of market research and strategies for business growth, risk management, possible exit strategies, etc. The unit will be delivered through a number of modules. As a vital part of the unit, students are expected to engage and work in “start-up co-working space” on a regular basis. As a tangible outcome, at the completion of this unit, students would have developed a future growth plan with an identification of possible exit strategies.
units.name: Incubator 7: Growth and Exit Strategies
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Conduct market research and identify possible business growth areas
2. Analyse competition and possible collaboration opportunities
3. Demonstrate an understanding of legal implications associated with expansion options
4. Analyse personal and organisational effects with various exit strategies

units.description:
This unit provides basic studies in the major areas of artificial intelligence: search, knowledge representation, logic programming, machine learning and knowledge based systems, agent planning and learning. The first part of this unit will focus on the foundation of artificial intelligence: search algorithms and their implementations, game playing, logics and knowledge representation, and inference in reasoning systems.
The second part will cover the principles of knowledge based systems (intelligent systems), planning, and machine learning.
units.assumedKnowledge: Basic understanding of data structures and algorithms and basic programming skills in Pascal, C/C++ or Java, etc
units.approachToLearning:
Lecture: The lectures present and explore the theoretical aspects of this unit, and allow for discussions of relevant theories, algorithm and problem solving tasks.

Tutorial: The tutorial sessions allow students to review and absorb the knowledge they study in lectures, and to communicate directly with the lecturer and other students for enhancing their learning.

Practical: The practical sessions allow students to undertake programming exercises related to the theories studied in lectures, and to receive both the lecturer mentoring along with feedback on their progress.
units.name: Artificial Intelligence
units.outcome:
Outcomes

1. Articulate the major concepts of artificial intelligence and knowledge based systems and their historical context
2. Implement well designed and various search algorithms for problem solving
3. Implement a well designed proper two-person game playing programs for specific tasks
4. Devise first order logics to formalise proper real world domains
5. Apply proper first order inference procedures to solve reasoning problems
6. Analyse the process of agent planning
7. Implement the Decision Tree Learning algorithm
units.unitPrerequisites: 200025 Discrete Mathematics, 300103 Data Structures and Algorithms

units.description: The Internet of Things (IoT) is drastically changing the way organisations operate and how individuals interact with the world. IoT is an infrastructure consisting of fairly constantly communicating objects, or things, that may be smart and process or act on data. The IoT facilitates detailed and meaningful interactions between humans, digital devices, and many other industrial and household equipment, appliances, and things. The IoT is also the enabler of smart environments, including smart homes, buildings, cities, transport, and healthcare, among many others. This unit discusses IoT technologies and applications in detail. It also introduces the students to trends, challenges, and key research topics in relevant areas.
units.assumedKnowledge: Students should be familiar with the fundamentals of computer networking. In particular, they should have a good understanding of the TCP/IP protocol suite, and current networking and wireless technologies. Therefore, it is strongly advisable that the students must have either taken an appropriate unit in computer networking (e.g., 300695 Network Technologies), or have equivalent knowledge.
units.approachToLearning: The unit includes lively discussions. The students are highly encouraged to attend all classes, which may include assessable tasks, including quizzes. The marked quizzes will be returned to students quickly, generally in the following class, to facilitate further discussions of the unit material. Students with any problems, concerns or doubts should discuss them with the unit coordinator as early as they can.
units.name: Internet of Things
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Demonstrate an in-depth knowledge of the IoT characteristics, trends, and architecture
2. Explain communication technologies of significant importance in the IoT
3. Describe the major IoT applications and demonstrate creative skills to plan their establishment or expansion
4. Describe security and privacy issues in the IoT and identify their remedies
5. Discuss the emerging trends in the IoT and smart environments
units.passCriteria:
satisfy the School that they have appropriately completed all mandatory components of the unit.  Satisfactory completion of a mandatory component includes a full attempt at the work designated and the demonstration of an appropriate level of knowledge of the component content.  Failure to do so will result in a 'Fail Non Submission' grade, regardless of the total mark achieved in the unit by the student. The mandatory components of this unit are:
- Quizzes
- Project report 
- Project presentation
- Intra-session Exam.

units.description: Advanced Mathematical Investigations is an integral part of the Master of Research for students planning a future in mathematical and/or statistical research. Students will carry out extensive investigations under the supervision of an academic staff member that will allow the development of skills, knowledge and a way of thinking that will assist in the learning of mathematics and/or statistics needed for research in their chosen field of mathematics. They will also develop their written and oral communication skills, culminating in a paper which will be written as though it is to be submitted to a mathematics/statistics journal for publication (including following the journal's requirements for presentation) and an oral presentation of the style expected at a mathematics/statistics conference.
units.assumedKnowledge: Undergraduate level of knowledge in mathematics or statistics
units.approachToLearning: This is a project based unit, so its main component is independent work on your project in consultation with your project supervisor.
units.name: Advanced Mathematical Investigations
units.outcome:
At the conclusion of this unit, students who have mastered all aspects should be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Plan and develop an investigative project
2. Locate, identify and use information relevant to the problem being studied
3. Write an extensive literature review
4. Undertake self-directed study relevant to the problem being investigated
5. Undertake a theoretical and/or analytical investigation
6. Write and produce a comprehensive research report in a logical, concise and professional manner
7. Present a project and its results to an audience in a talk
8. Prepare results of research for submission to a mathematics or statistics journal for publication
units.passCriteria:
1. Participate in the oral presentations (both of which are mandatory) AND
2. Submit the literature review and outline, final written report and the professional task (all of which are mandatory) AND
3. Achieve an overall mark of at least 50%.
Note: Failure to submit any of the written reports or non-participation in any of the student presentation sessions will result in a FNS (Fail Non-submission) grade, unless Special Consideration is granted in accordance with UWS policies.

units.description: This unit is designed to enable the student to classify diseases and interventions using the current version of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems, Tenth Revision, Australian Modification, the Australian Classification of Health Interventions and the Australian Coding Standards (ICD-10-AM/ACHI/ACS). The unit will also include the historical development of clinical classification systems as well as the purpose and value of classifying diseases and interventions within the health system. The students will become familiar with the structure and content of ICD-10-AM ACHI/ACS and be introduced to the rules and conventions associated within ICD-10-AM/ACHI. Further, students will carry out research based analytical tasks gaining an in-depth knowledge in relation to health classification systems and terminology systems such as SNOMED-CT (Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine - Clinical Terms).
units.assumedKnowledge: Student must have a general knowledge in relation to healthcare systems
units.approachToLearning:
The unit content will be delivered in 12 modules. Generally, one module will be covered in one week. Weekly class time is 4 hours, which is divided into two parts as a lecture (2 hrs) and a workshop (2hrs). The lecture and tutorial will be delivered in a Parramatta South campus SoCDMS specialised lab. The other two campuses will be linked up with through zoom from Penrith (Y.2.39) and Campbelltown (26.1.50). Students have the following options in attending the classes:
(1) attend the class in Parramatta (preferred)
(2) attend the session via zoom from Campbelltown or Penrith locations and connect to Parramatta.
(3) join from outside the university and connect with the Parramatta location using Zoom technology (see below for zoom meeting details).

ZOOM Video Conferencing Details
TIME: Tuesdays from 2nd March 2020 -4th June 2020 (see the schedule of activities for more information) from 6:00 pm-10:00 pm
Go to https://uws.zoom.us, click on ’Join a Meeting’ button and enter the meeting ID 5769033312.
First time setup may take about 10 mins.

Resources for the class: 
It is expected that students have access to the TurboCoder Software∗ on your computer or hard-copies of the latest edition (10th) of ICD-10-AM/ACHI/ACS books∗∗.  
∗ TurboCoder Software can be purchased from https://www.ecompress.com/buyICD10AMs10th.htm.
∗∗ICD-10-AM/ACHI/ACS books can be purchased from - http://ar-drg.laneprint.com.au/ (student discounts are available).  

TurboCoder Software is available in SCEM lab machines. Details on how to use the software in SCEM labs will be provided via vUWs site. Please note TurboCoder Software only works on Windows operating system. If you have a Mac computer, it is suggested that you install Windows on your Mac with Boot Camp (see instructions here https://support.apple.com/en-au/HT201468).

To support your learning in this unit, you will have access to the unit’s site on the university’s e-learning system vUWS. The unit’s vUWS site is the place where you can find all the relevant information related to this unit. You will get access to module content including lecture notes, workshop notes and exercises. To access vUWS, go to https://vuws.westernsydney.edu.au. You will require a current WesternAccount to login to vUWS. Once logged in, you will see links to all the units you are currently enrolled in. vUWS will be used as the main communication channel between the unit coordinator and students. The students should consult vUWS at least twice a week, as all unit announcements will be made via vUWS.
units.name: Advanced Health Classifications and Coding
units.outcome:
ICD-10 (International Classification of Diseases, 10th Edition) is the foundation for the identification of health trends and statistics globally, and the international standard for reporting diseases and health conditions. ICD defines the diseases, disorders, injuries and other related health conditions. ICD coded data allows:
- easy computer-based storage, retrieval and analysis of health information for evidence-based decision-making;
- sharing and comparing health information between hospitals, regions, settings and countries; and
- data comparisons in the same location across different periods.

ICD-10-AM is the Australian Modification of the international standard, used in Australia. In this unit, students will get an introduction to ICD-10-AM latest edition and associated classification systems. These associated classification systems include ACHI (Australian Classification of Health Interventions) and ACS (Australian Coding Standards).

As future health informaticians, students must have a sound comprehension of these classification systems. Hence at the successful completion of this unit students can:

Outcomes 1. Summarise the history and development of ICD-10-AM/ACHI/ACS 2. Analytically represent the difference between a statistical classification and a nomenclature through independent research 3. Correctly apply the principles and techniques of clinical classification to code diagnoses and interventions using ICD-10-AM/ACHI/ACS 4. Identify and interpret diagnostic and therapeutic test results and accurately classify findings based on qualification from within the clinical record 5. Analyse diagnostic and procedural statements, case studies and simple discharge summaries/clinical record reports to determine which clinical statements to abstract and classify 6. Source further information to clarify complex clinical coding issues 7. Explain the use of clinical classification systems in health care, describing their purpose and value
units.passCriteria:
- Complete all assessment items,
- Score a minimum of 90% of the total allocated marks (36 out of 40) in the FINAL PRACTICAL TEST (students are allowed 3 attempts to achieve this score), and
- Score an overall mark of 50% or above in the unit.

units.description: This unit introduces the most fundamental techniques of artificial intelligence (AI), including knowledge representation, searching, machine learning and intelligent agents. Students will learn the basic theories and algorithms that are essential in the design and development of intelligent systems. The unit will focus on two typical AI applications: game playing and e-trading. Students will have the chance of using existing multiagent system platforms to design and develop intelligent software for game playing and automated trading in e-markets.
units.assumedKnowledge: This unit requires basic skills in programming with either JAVA or C++ as the programming language.
units.approachToLearning:
This unit enhances learning through lectures, tutorials, assignments, textbook and other online materials.

Lectures - explain the fundamental concepts of artificial intelligence with selected topics. Lecture notes are available on vUWS. Students are expected to preview associated lecture notes before each lecture and view the lecture notes again after the lecture.

Tutorials - provide students with questions and hands-on experience designed to challenge them to think about and feel intelligent systems with detailed instructions or hints. Opportunities are there for students to ask questions and discuss among themselves. Attendance to the tutorials is compulsory.

Assignments - The first assignment will be purely theoretical, which is designed for enhancing a good understanding of the fundamental knowledge of Artificial Intelligence. The second assignment provides students with an opportunity of building an intelligent system or intelligent agents.

Textbook - the text provides detailed theories, algorithms, explanations and examples of and beyond what are covered in the lecture notes. Students should preview and review the related chapters of textbook for each lecture and tutorial. 

vUWS - is used as the main communication channel with students. Students should check the mail and announcement facility frequently to be aware of changes, hints or recommendations made during the session. A discussion facility is also available to enable students to share ideas.
units.name: Advanced Topics in Artificial Intelligence
units.outcome:
After a successful completion of this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Explain the background and principles of typical artificial intelligence techniques
2. Describe the algorithms and their applications of typical artificial intelligence techniques
3. Describe the architectures and models of intelligent agents and robots
4. Explain the general economic model of electronic markets
5. Design and implement computer game players and trading agents based on provided system development environment

To pass this unit, you must achieve at least 50% overall.

units.description: This unit, the first half of Amazon Web Services (AWS) Academy Cloud Computing Architecture curriculum, provides deep understanding of fundamental cloud computing concepts and how it can be applied to build cost-effective; highly available and fault tolerant systems. Students will learn concepts including system virtualisation; virtual machines; cloud networks; basic cloud storage and cloud databases; security in clouds; and auto-scaling, load balancing, and monitoring. All these aspects are explored in practice with AWS services.
units.approachToLearning:
The lectures and text reading will examine the theoretical aspects related to Cloud Computing. We have a weekly face-to-face lecture to present some topics of the unit.

The practical activities are designed so that you will gain expertise in becoming a con dent and competent user of Cloud technology. Students will be asked to practice the topics during tutorials for each module of the unit.

units.outcome:

2. Explain and apply basic cloud services
3. Describe the main factors that affect the cost of cloud services and how they can be applied to minimise total cost of ownership
4. Explain and apply basic concepts of security, high availability, and fault tolerance in clouds
5. Analyse systems that utilise basic cloud services

units.description: This unit, the second part of the Amazon Web Services (AWS) Academy Cloud Computing Architecture curriculum, provides deeper understanding about advanced cloud computing services and how to architect cloud applications that are scalable, reliable, and efficient in terms of cost and performance. Students will learn advanced cloud computing concepts including notification and messaging, serverless computing, API gateways, NoSQL databases, content delivery networks, stream processing, and long-term storage. The unit also covers advanced cloud security and infrastructure automation. All these aspects are explored in practice with AWS services. Upon completion of this unit, students will be prepared for the AWS Certified Solutions Architect – Associate exam.
units.approachToLearning:
Lecture: The lectures examine theoretical aspects of cloud computing and how to architect cloud computing applications.

Practical: Practical classes include discussion of questions and completion of lab work. These activities are designed to test and deepen the students understanding of knowledge and to develop practical skills.
units.name: Cloud Computing Architecture
units.outcome:
Outcomes

1. Assess different design patterns for web-scale storage and recommend the most appropriate pattern for a specific problem
2. Analyze common design patterns and architectures for loosely coupled cloud computing systems and recommend the most appropriate pattern for a specific problem
3. Evaluate strategies to enable high scalability, reliability, cost-efficiency, and performance in a cloud-based system
4. Apply principles and applications of advanced cloud services such as notification and messaging, API gateways, stream processing, and serverless computing
5. Apply concepts of security and infrastructure automation in a cloud-based system
6. Design and deploy scalable, reliable, and efficient systems that utilise advanced cloud services

units.description: Robot Operating System (ROS) is a software integration system that is now widely used for robotics software deployment. The philosophy behind ROS is to modularise software that can work for other robots through small changes in the code. This unit focuses on the main concepts of software development under ROS by looking at the file hierarchical systems (e.g. Packages, Stacks, Messages, Services and others), module communication types through Nodes, Topics, Services, Messages, Bags, Master and how they integrate to operate robot sensors and actuators. This unit also looks at actual AI software examples using C++/Python and Answer Set Programming (ASP).
units.assumedKnowledge: Basic knowledge of Linux, C++/Python and Object Oriented Programming (OOP)
units.approachToLearning: This is a 10 credit points unit, which requires diligence and effort from your part to obtain the maximum possible marks available. It is expected that you will spend on average 10 hours a week: 4 hours face-to-face (lectures/tutorials/practicals) and 6 hours self-study per week. The unit coordinator will provide the lecture notes, tutorial questions, practical questions and reading materials each week to aid the delivery of the unit's content. The lecture notes and tutorial questions will aid with the students theoretical knowledge, while the practical activities will let students gain hands on experience with developing robotic programs under the ROS framework.
units.name: Robotic Programming
units.outcome:
The unit provided students with an in-depth introduction to the Robot Operating System (ROS). ROS is a software integration system that is now widely used for robotics software deployment. The philosophy behind ROS is to modularise software that can work for other robots through small changes in the codes. This unit focuses on the main concepts of software development under ROS by looking at the file hierarchical systems (e.g., Packages, Stacks, Messages, Services, etc.,  and others), module communication types through Nodes, Topics, Services, Messages, Bags, Master and how they integrate to operate robot sensors and actuators. This unit also looks at actual AI software examples using C++/Python and Answer Set Programming (ASP). 

 Outcomes

1. Describe the software systems for robotics.
2. Illustrate how drivers written for various robot parts are viewed as nodes and services under the ROS system framework.
3. Explain how different ‘processes’ made for other applications can be incorporated onto their own software projects under ROS through the use of standard/predefined topics.
4. Describe how various state-of-the-art AI software can be embedded into a ROS system by having them as a backend for certain ROS processing tasks (nodes).
5. Develop software for interacting with sensor and controlling actuators using ROS tools.
6. Develop software using current state-of-the-art AI systems as backend for processes as ROS Nodes.
units.unitPrerequisites: 300147 and 300167 Object Oriented Programming and Systems Programming 1, 300147 and 300698 Object Oriented Programming and Operating Systems Programming, 300043 Mobile Robotics
units.passCriteria:
1.) Get at least 50% of all the total available marks, i.e.: Total Available Marks = Practicals + Quiz I + Quiz II + Assignment.
2.) Get at least 50% of all the total available Quiz marks, i.e.:  Total Quiz Marks = Quiz I + Quiz II.
3.) Get at least 50% of all the total Practical marks.

units.description: There are unavoidable legal situations and ethical dilemmas in all professions. As an entrepreneur, facing these legal and ethical circumstances is much more formidable. This unit aims to prepare students to understand the legal and ethical landscape that applies to start-up (or any) organisation. As such, unit aims to cover the topics such as: creating a business plan, negotiating employment contracts, etc. The unit will be delivered through a number of modules. As an integral part of the unit, students are expected to engage and work in “start-up co-working space” on a regular basis. At the successful completion of this unit, students would have developed a thorough understanding of the local and international legal and ethical landscape within which modern start-up organisations operate.
units.approachToLearning:
The unit is developed around key stages for creating, validating, developing and pitching a software application and associated startup:
1.	Ideate – develop and refine a business model through business model canvas  
2.	Validate – test and challenge business model with market data and feedback
3.	Build – rapidly develop and test prototype applying theoretical knowledge  
4.	Pitch – develop investor docs & deliver pitch presentation

Three key components are designed to support students creating, validating, developing and pitching a software application and associated Startup:
•	Online:
o	The Udacity Course “How To Build a Startup” contains 11 online lessons that students must complete as scheduled
o	Additional Unit Advisory Modules designed to provide addition advice and insights must be completed as scheduled
•	Launchpad events, workshops, and mentoring sessions
o	Weekly Sessions delivered at the Launchpad Facility linked to key stages
•	Students Working on the software applications and Startups
o	Students will work on developing their concept, new technology, or software application and startup business either located at the Launchpad facility or remotely    

This unit effectively provides a full introduction to a “Lean Startup” approach to creating and developing a software application and a startup business – but in practice students will only be able to produce initial concepts at this early stage of their degree. This approach and elements of it will be revisited in future Incubator units as students fully develop their software applications and associated startups.

vUWS – all announcements and teaching materials, including all assignments, are accessible via vUWS. All submissions must be electronic and through the submission page at the unit website. Students are required to visit the unit website for the latest announcement on a regular basis (at least twice a week).
units.name: Incubator 2: Start-up Essentials
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing the unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Develop a disruptive hypothesis for a business opportunity
2. Develop multiple business model options using lean start-up tools
3. Validate business models in the market using customer development and manual testing tactics
4. Understand rapidly prototyping products to validate a customer solution
5. Adapt and create business models when core ideas are not validated in the market
units.passCriteria:
There are three assessment components in this unit, designed to enable you to demonstrate that you have achieved the unit learning outcomes. The assessment components are also set up to assist you in identifying the legal aspects that may affect your startup enterprise and help you with establishing a strategy for addressing those. Completion and submission of all assessment items which have been designated as mandatory or compulsory is essential to receive a passing grade. 

To pass this unit you must:
-	An overall mark of at least 50% is required to pass this unit.

units.description: This unit focuses on the advanced features of Cybersecurity, contemporary views on security, and the solutions that aim to protect the emerging services and technologies. The emphasis is on the development of student skills to enable them to do proficient research and development works and studies in the cybersecurity discipline. On successful completion of this unit, students will be equipped with an in-depth understanding of relevant issues, attacks on massively interconnected systems, and the evolving approaches to improve the reliability of advanced services.
units.assumedKnowledge: The students should be familiar with the fundamentals of computer networking and security. It is advisable that the students must have either taken appropriate units in these areas (e.g., 300695 Network Technologies and 300696 Systems and Network Security) or have equivalent knowledge.
units.approachToLearning: The unit includes lively discussions. The students are highly encouraged to attend all classes, which may include assessable tasks, including progress meetings and presentations. Students with any problems, concerns or doubts should discuss them with the unit coordinator as early as they can.
units.name: Advanced Topics in Cybersecurity
units.outcome:
Upon successfully completing this unit, students will be able to:

 Outcomes

1. Describe the important concepts applicable to the emerging cybersecurity-related approaches and technologies
2. Analyse the vital cybersecurity issues in modern applications and services
3. Explain the contemporary issues in security and reliability of modern massively interconnected systems
4. Evaluate the performance of the emerging cybersecurity solutions and the related technologies
5. Demonstrate proficiency with key research and development issues in the fields of cybercrime and cybersecurity
units.passCriteria:
Satisfy the School that they have appropriately completed all mandatory components of the unit. Satisfactory completion of a mandatory component includes a full attempt at the work designated and the demonstration of an appropriate level of knowledge of the component content. Failure to do so will result in a ’Fail Non Submission’ grade, regardless of the total mark achieved in the unit by the student. 
The mandatory components of this unit are:
- Short reports
- Project report and its presentation
- Intra-session Exam.

units.description: This unit introduces the foundation and concepts underpinning Machine Learning (ML) at a more abstract level, and provides more focus on its practical applications in areas such as: the classification and extraction of text data from various documents and web pages, image processing, Google’s PageRank algorithm and relational data mining (RDM). These learning objectives are achieved through various ML software and a series of practicals and projects. The unit covers the concepts and notions of supervised, unsupervised and reinforcement learning, perceptron, neural networks, support vector machines (SVM), knowledge representation (KR) based RDM, and a comprehensive introduction to the Scikit-learn ML Python libraries.
units.assumedKnowledge: Some probability and statistics knowledge would be advantageous.
units.approachToLearning: This is a 10 credit points unit, which requires diligence and effort from your part to obtain the maximum possible marks available. It is expected that you will spend on average 10 hours a week: 4 hours face-to-face (lectures/tutorials/practicals) and 6 hours self-study per week. The unit coordinator will provide the lecture notes, tutorial questions, practical questions and reading materials each week to aid the delivery of the unit's content. The lecture notes and tutorial questions will aid with the students theoretical knowledge, while the practical activities will let students gain hands on experience with developing and applying machine learning softwares.
units.name: Applied Machine Learning
units.outcome:
This unit introduces the foundation and concepts underpinning Machine Learning (ML) at a more abstract level, and provides more focus on its practical applications in areas such as: the classification and extraction of text data from various documents and web pages, image processing, Google’s Page Rank algorithm and relational data mining (RDM). These learning objectives are achieved through various ML software and a series of practicals and projects. The unit covers the concepts and notions of supervised, unsupervised and reinforcement learning, perceptron, neural networks, support vector machines (SVM), knowledge representation (KR) based RDM, and a comprehensive introduction to the Scikit-learn ML Python libraries.

Upon completion of this unit, students are expected to:

Outcomes 1. Analyse the scope of current machine learning approaches and applications for both current and future use. 2. Determine the most appropriate tools to use for machine learning tasks using software applications including Python and R programming languages. 3. Explain the core principles behind machine learning algorithms. 4. Distinguish between supervised, unsupervised and reinforcement learning notions. 5. Apply Machine Learning software to real-world problems.

units.description: Natural Language Understanding involves machine reading comprehension and the technologies using it are becoming increasingly widespread. This unit provides a foundation in using the Natural Language Toolkit, which is a leading platform for building Python programs working with ‘human language’ data, as well as an introduction to Python for Natural Language Processing. Students will use algorithms and explore accessing text corpora and processing raw text; categorising words and classifying text; understanding information from text and analysing sentence structures; and understanding semantic meanings of sentences. Students also gain real-world hands-on experience with Natural Language Understanding through the practical tasks and assignments.
units.assumedKnowledge: There are no assumed knowledge for this unit although an undergraduate degree with some probability and statistics is advantageous.
units.approachToLearning: This is a 10 credit points unit, which requires diligence and effort from your part to obtain the maximum possible marks available. It is expected that you will spend on average 10 hours a week: 4 hours face-to-face (lectures/tutorials/practicals) and 6 hours self-study per week. The unit coordinator will provide the lecture notes, tutorial questions, practical questions and reading materials each week to aid the delivery of the unit’s content. The lecture notes and tutorial questions will aid with the students theoretical knowledge, while the practical activities will let students gain hands on experience with developing and applying natural language understanding softwares.
units.name: Natural Language Understanding
units.outcome:
It has long been recognized that understanding how we process language (spoken and written) is key to understanding how we communicate. In this unit you will learn about computational aspects of language:

  • how to represent it in precise mathematical forms.
  • use syntactic constructs to find information about text documents.
  • search for specific structure.
  • tag and classify words and documents.
  • understand meaning and represent it mathematically.
  • train machines to perform useful linguistic tasks like providing information in a natural
    language, recognize languages and more.

In this unit you will be evaluated on weekly lab exercises, 2 assignments and a final examination. Upon completion of this unit, students are expected to:

Outcomes 1. Apply the Natural Language Toolkit to real world Natural Language Processing tasks. 2. Use text corpora for the engineering and evaluation of Natural Language Processing systems. 3. Determine the role of classification of words and text in Natural Language Processing algorithms. 4. Clarify the function of Natural Language Processing algorithms in understanding information from text and the semantic meanings of sentences. 5. Analyse artificial intelligence techniques employed in Natural Language Processing algorithms. 6. Manage linguistic data.

blocks.name: Fundamentals of Object-Orientation (OO) – Starting the OO Journey

activities.name:
Lecture: OO Fundamentals:
- Concepts (Class, Object, Message)
- Principles Classification, Abstraction, Inheritance, Encapsulation and Polymorphism) 
- Modelling spaces
Tutorial: No tutorials in the week.

blocks.name: The Unified Modelling Language in Object Oriented Analysis

activities.name:
Lecture: UML in a nutshell:
- What comprises the UML
- The purpose it serves, and 
- A walkthrough of 13 UML 2.0 diagrams.
Project Work 1: Students to form groups of FOUR to work on the project. All actual group work will be carried out in the Tutorial sessions in the Labs

Lecture: Understanding software processing
- Its relevance to the UML
- Iterative, Incremental, and Parallel process
- The process architecture and elements: Roles, Activities, Deliverables  
- Specific discussion: Business analysis and Requirements Modelling process-component. 
 + Critical Requirement Analysis for Prioritization. 
 + Package Diagrams
Project Work 2: Students should informally experiment creating these diagrams in their CASE tool - individually and in groups.

blocks.name: Use Case Models: Actors, Use cases and Documentation

activities.name:
Lecture: Modelling the requirements in the form of Use cases
- System scope: What and Who
- Use Cases
- Actors
- High level UC documentation using a Template
Project Work 3: Undertake Critical Requirement Analysis, Identification and prioritization of Package, Creation of an IIP Project Plan.

blocks.name: Use Case Diagrams and Activity Diagrams; UML’s Extensibility Mechanisms

activities.name:
Lecture: - Use case diagrams – visual modelling
 + Placing Actors and Use cases on use case diagrams. 
- Creation of activity diagrams. 
- UML extensibility 
 + Studying stereotypes and notes. 
Project Work 4: Identify Actors and Use cases based on the Problem Statement. Document them separately for each Package.

Lecture: - Revisit classes and objects 
- Modelling tasks:
 + Extract classes from use cases and activity diagrams
 + Model classes - define Attributes and Operations of Classes
 + Relate classes 
 + Create Class diagrams
Project Work 5: Create use case diagrams; Create corresponding activity diagrams. Apply stereotypes and notes to diagrams.

blocks.name: Sequence Diagrams; Interaction Overview Diagrams; State Machines

activities.name:
Lecture: Modelling Interaction (in use cases/activity diagrams) 
- Sequence diagrams. 
- Interaction overview diagrams. 
- Modelling dynamic object states
- State machine diagrams. 
Project Work 6: Identify classes from use case documentation and problem statement. Model classes with attributes and operations. Create class diagrams and apply multiplicities, stereotypes and notes

Lecture: Specification of Interfaces in the problem space:
- Graphic User Interfaces
- Creation of navigation maps for front-ends and web sites. 
- Mapping sequences to Interfaces. 
- Prototypes as models. 
Project Work 7: Create sequence diagrams for sequences identified in use cases / or activity diagrams. Also, create state machines for selected object/classes from the class diagrams.
Tutorial: Not marked tutorial (self study for mid-term revision)

Lecture: - The CLOSED book test conducted DURING LECTURE TIME. 
- For 80 minutes including reading time
- Test the knowledge gained by the students thus far (up to Lecture 6), as well as provide them with a feedback on how they are progressing.

blocks.name: Intra-session Exam
blocks.due_date: Week 10 (beginning 04/05/20): Parramatta Mon. 11:00-13:00; Campbelltown Wed. 11:00-13:00; Penrith Thu. 11:00-13:00

activities.name:
Lecture: Quality management:
- Quality assurance and quality control
- Planning and organizing testing for units (e.g. use cases) 
- Writing good test cases. 
Project Work 8: Create interface specifications corresponding to interface actors within use cases. Create navigation maps. Create possible prototype interfaces.

blocks.name:
Operational Requirements in Analysis
Feedback to Intra-session Exam

activities.name:
Lecture: Operational issues:
- Performance, Scalability, Security & Volume 
- Their specifications during analysis work. 
Project Work 9: Write a mini Test Plan; Write test cases corresponding to use cases with valid and invalid input.
Discuss on web technologies:
- Web services and emerging technologies
- Web services and modelling
- Web services dynamics

blocks.name:

Final Discussion on Project

activities.name:

Discussion on Project:
- Revision of project, binding and submission (together with soft copies of OO Analysis Report, UML models and Project Plans)
- Sorting of outstanding issues in Project
Project Work 10: Specify operational requirements; specify development environment for your project.

Lecture: Understanding web vulnerabilities, use of SSL, certificates, trust. Understanding man in the middle attacks, XSS.

- Understand how SSL works and provide security report on your favourite website. - Understand and use TOR. 
- Prepare a simple XSS.

Lecture: Violating the rules of engagement or going out of scope is the biggest mistake a penetration tester can make. The rules of engagement include laws and ethical guidelines as well as types of tests that are allowed to be performed in a specific engagement. The scope are things that you are allowed to test in that engagement. Going out of bounds on either of these can not only be career limiting, but also freedom limiting. When in doubt always go back to the written rules of engagement and scope. Ask for clarification or modification if required. There is no cheating in penetration testing. Only those things that are illegal, immoral, unethical, or illogical.
Practical: - Research and analyse cyber security policies

Lecture: Understand means of detecting a cyber attack, analysis of its complexity and liveness and means of preventing it in the future.

Explore means of exploration and investigation of passed cyber attacks, possibilities from their recovery. Recapitualtion and exam preparation.

Practical: - Use internet to find about various security terms and their way in helping attack detection and prevention. 
- Contemplate means of performing attack at given target. 
- Find means of preventing it. 
- Perform DOS on a network node.

- Follow scenarios for digital forensic methods. 
- Recuperate data from past cyber attack.

Lecture: Logarithms; exponentials; trigonometric functions and their inverses; hyperbolic functions and their inverses.

Lecture: Definition; basic operations; Argand diagram; polar form; Eulers formula; deMoivres’ theorem; roots and powers.
Lecture Quiz
Tutorial: Discussion related to Lecture 1. Each week, you should attempt weekly practice questions on vUWS and check solutions before attending class.
Lecture: Limit of a function; laws of limits; one-sided limits; vertical asymptotes; the squeeze theorem; continuity; intermediate value theorem.
Tutorial: Class Test 1. To prepare you should revise Lecture 1 and the associated tutorial questions.

blocks.name: Tutorial Test 1
blocks.due_date: Week 3 (Held in your allocated tutorial: Campbelltown Thursday 19 March 2020, 3:00-3:45pm; Parramatta Monday 16 March 2020, 4:00-4:45pm OR Monday 16 March 2020,  5:00-5:45pm)

activities.name:
Lecture: Limits involving infinity; horizontal asymptotes. 
Extension work - the precise definition of a limit. 
Lecture Quiz
Lecture: Consequences of the definition of the derivative; relationship between differentiability and continuity; derivatives of polynomials and exponential functions.
Lecture: Product and quotient rules; derivatives of trigonometric functions and their inverses; chain rule; implicit differentiation.
Tutorial: Class Test 2. To prepare you should revise Lectures 2, 3 & 4 and the associated tutorial questions.

blocks.name: Tutorial Test 2
blocks.due_date: Week 6 (Held in your allocated tutorial: Campbelltown Thursday 9 April 2020, 3:00-3:45pm; Parramatta Monday 6 April 2020, 4:00-4:45pm OR Monday 6 April 2020,  5:00-5:45pm)

blocks.name: No classes due to Easter Monday affecting Parramatta Classes. Accordingly, no classes will be held at Campbelltown during this week.

activities.name:
Lecture: Derivatives of logarithmic functions; logarithmic differentiation. Extension work - proofs in calculus -chain rule.
Lecture Quiz (Campbelltown only)
Lecture: Related rates; linear approximations; differentials; derivatives of hyperbolic functions and their inverses.
Tutorial: Class Test 3. To prepare you should revise Lectures 5 & 6 and the associated tutorial questions.

blocks.name: Tutorial Test 3
blocks.due_date: Week 10 (Held in your allocated tutorial: Campbelltown Thursday 7 May 2020, 3:00-3:45pm; Parramatta Monday 4 May 2020, 4:00-4:45pm OR Monday 4 May 2020,  5:00-5:45pm)

activities.name:
Lecture: Maximum and minimum values; extreme value theorem; Rolle’s Theorem; mean value theorem; first and second derivative tests.
Lecture Quiz

Lecture: Applied maximum and minimum problems; Newton’s Method;
Extension work - proofs in calculus -Mean Value Theorem and l’Hopital’s Rule.
Tutorial: Class Test 4. To prepare you should study Lectures 7, 8 & 9 and the associated tutorial questions.

blocks.name: Tutorial Test 4
blocks.due_date: Week 13 (Held in your allocated tutorial: Campbelltown Thursday 28 May 2020, 3:00-3:45pm; Parramatta Monday 25 May 2020, 4:00-4:45pm OR Monday 25 May 2020,  5:00-5:45pm)

activities.name:
Lecture: Antiderivatives; indefinite and definite integrals.
Lecture Quiz
Lecture: Riemann sums; definition of the definite integral. Text reference 5.1 5.2
Tutorial: Throughout the semester please see vUWS for various videos highlighting some important concepts in this unit. Also check the sample test papers
Lecture: Fundamental theorem of calculus; indefinite integrals; integration by substitution; the logarithm defined as an integral. Text reference: 5.3,5.4,5.5, Appendix G
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 2 lectures before checking with the solutions
Lecture: Integration by parts; trigonometric integrals; trigonometric substitutions. Text reference: 7.1,7.2,7.3
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 3 lectures before checking with the solutions.
Lecture: Partial fractions; improper integrals. Text reference: 7.4,7.5,7.8
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 4 lectures before checking with the solutions.

Lecture: A selection of topics from: areas and volumes; average value of a function; separable differentiable equations; exponential growth and decay; volumes using cylindrical shells; work; arc length; area of a surface of revolution; hydrostatic pressure and force; moments and centres of mass; consumer surplus; blood  flow; cardiac output; probability. Text reference: 6.1-6.5, 8.1-8.5, 9.3, 9.4
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 5 lectures before checking with the solutions.
Lecture: A selection of topics from above. Text reference: See above
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 6 lectures before checking with the solutions
Lecture: A selection of topics from above text reference: See above
Lecture: Systems of linear equations; properties of determinants; Cramers rule; operations on matrices; inverse of a matrix. Text reference: N/A
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 9 lectures before checking with the solutions.
Lecture: Matrix row reduction (Gauss-Jordan and Gaussian); inverse of a matrix by reduction; eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Text reference: N/A
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 10 lectures before checking with the solutions.
Lecture: Definitions of sequences and series; integral test and estimates of sums; comparison tests; alternating series. Text reference: 11.1-11.5
Tutorial: Attempt the tutorial questions related to week 11 lectures before checking with the solutions.
Lecture: Absolute convergence; ratio and root tests; power series; Taylor and Maclaurin series; application of Taylor polynomials. Text reference: 11.6, 11.8-11.11
Lecture: Basic operations; dot product; cross product; equations of lines and planes in three dimensional space. Text reference: 12.1-12.5
Lecture: Attempt the sample exam paper.
Tutorial: Attempt the sample exam before checking with the solutions.

Lecture: UML in a nutshell:
- What comprises the UML
- The purpose it serves, and 
- A walkthrough of 13 UML 2.0 diagrams.
Project Work 1: Students to form groups of FOUR to work on the project. All actual group work will be carried out in the Tutorial sessions in the Labs

Lecture: Understanding software processing
- Its relevance to the UML
- Iterative, Incremental, and Parallel process
- The process architecture and elements: Roles, Activities, Deliverables  
- Specific discussion: Business analysis and Requirements Modelling process-component. 
 + Critical Requirement Analysis for Prioritization. 
 + Package Diagrams
Project Work 2: Students should informally experiment creating these diagrams in their CASE tool - individually and in groups.

Project Work 4: Identify Actors and Use cases based on the Problem Statement. Document them separately for each Package.

Lecture: - Revisit classes and objects 
- Modelling tasks:
 + Extract classes from use cases and activity diagrams
 + Model classes - define Attributes and Operations of Classes
 + Relate classes 
 + Create Class diagrams
Project Work 5: Create use case diagrams; Create corresponding activity diagrams. Apply stereotypes and notes to diagrams.

blocks.name: Sequence Diagrams; Interaction Overview Diagrams; State Machines

activities.name:
Lecture: Modelling Interaction (in use cases/activity diagrams) 
- Sequence diagrams. 
- Interaction overview diagrams. 
- Modelling dynamic object states
- State machine diagrams. 
Project Work 6: Identify classes from use case documentation and problem statement. Model classes with attributes and operations. Create class diagrams and apply multiplicities, stereotypes and notes

Lecture: Specification of Interfaces in the problem space:
- Graphic User Interfaces
- Creation of navigation maps for front-ends and web sites. 
- Mapping sequences to Interfaces. 
- Prototypes as models. 
Project Work 7: Create sequence diagrams for sequences identified in use cases / or activity diagrams. Also, create state machines for selected object/classes from the class diagrams.
Lecture: OOA (Adv.) students will NOT sit the Intro-session Exam during the lecture of this week.

Lecture: Quality management:
- Quality assurance and quality control
- Planning and organizing testing for units (e.g. use cases) 
- Writing good test cases. 
Project Work 8: Create interface specifications corresponding to interface actors within use cases. Create navigation maps. Create possible prototype interfaces.

Lecture: Operational issues:
- Performance, Scalability, Security & Volume 
- Their specifications during analysis work. 
Project Work 9: Write a mini Test Plan; Write test cases corresponding to use cases with valid and invalid input.
Discuss on web technologies:
- Web services and emerging technologies
- Web services and modelling
- Web services dynamics
- Web services in practices
Discussion on Project:
- Revision of project, binding and submission (together with soft copies of OO Analysis Report, UML models and Project Plans)
- Sorting of outstanding issues in Project
Project Work 10: Specify operational requirements; specify development environment for your project.

jobs.name: Analyst Programmer
jobs.description:
Analyses user needs, produces requirements documentation and system plans, and encodes, tests, debugs, maintains
and documents programs and applications.

**Description of Employment Duties:**

- researching, consulting, analysing and evaluating system program needs
- identifying technology limitations and deficiencies in existing systems and associated processes, procedures
and methods
- testing, debugging, diagnosing and correcting errors and faults in an applications programming language
within established testing protocols, guidelines and quality standards to ensure programs and applications
perform to specification
- writing and maintaining program code to meet system requirements, system designs and technical
specifications in accordance with quality accredited standards
- writing, updating and maintaining technical program, end user documentation and operational procedures
- providing advice, guidance and expertise in developing proposals and strategies for software design activities
such as financial evaluation and costing for recommending software purchases and upgrades

items.name: Ethics
Professional Expectations
items.description: Topics covered should include: expertise, certification, competence, autonomy, excellence, reflection, responsibility and accountability

items.name: Teamwork Concepts & Issues
items.description:
Topics covered should include: collaboration,
group dynamics, leadership styles, conflict
resolution, team development and groupware

items.name: Communication
items.description:
Topics covered should include: oral and
written presentations, technical report
writing, writing user documentation and the
development of effective interpersonal skills.

items.name: Societal Issues
items.description:
Topics covered should include: history of
computing and the ICT discipline, privacy
and civil liberties, cybercrime, intellectual
property and legal issues.

items.name: Understand of ICT Profession
items.description:
Professionals should have some knowledge
of where and when their discipline began
and how it has evolved, in addition to
understanding of ongoing issues in the
discipline.

items.name: Problem Solving Abstraction
items.description:
This requires knowledge of how to use
modelling methods and processes to
understand problems, handle abstraction and
design solutions.

The methods and tools that are used for
handling abstraction could vary a great deal
with the branch of ICT, from circuit diagrams
to data modelling tools to business process
modelling.

It is important to recognise this area
because it captures some of the creativity
and innovation that is required of ICT
professionals, and the excitement that is
present in their jobs. Recognising this component also assists in identifying what is unique about ICT and what differentiates it
from other disciplines. In no other discipline
is there such an emphasis on developing
artefacts (e.g., computer and information
systems) which are so abstract and complex
and where modelling tools and methods are
essential. The systems that ICT professionals
deal with cannot be seen or handled in the
same simple and direct manner as products
of other applied disciplines (e.g., buildings,
bridges, chairs, drugs). Consequently, highly
developed problem solving skills and the
need for methods to handle abstraction and
modelling are absolutely vital.

items.name: Problem Solving Design
items.description:
This requires knowledge of how to use
modelling methods and processes to
understand problems, handle abstraction and
design solutions.

The methods and tools that are used for
handling abstraction could vary a great deal
with the branch of ICT, from circuit diagrams
to data modelling tools to business process
modelling.

It is important to recognise this area
because it captures some of the creativity
and innovation that is required of ICT
professionals, and the excitement that is
present in their jobs. Recognising this component also assists in identifying what is unique about ICT and what differentiates it
from other disciplines. In no other discipline
is there such an emphasis on developing
artefacts (e.g., computer and information
systems) which are so abstract and complex
and where modelling tools and methods are
essential. The systems that ICT professionals
deal with cannot be seen or handled in the
same simple and direct manner as products
of other applied disciplines (e.g., buildings,
bridges, chairs, drugs). Consequently, highly
developed problem solving skills and the
need for methods to handle abstraction and
modelling are absolutely vital.

items.name: Hardware and Software Fundamentals
items.description:
An understanding of the basic components of
computer systems is required, including:
- Computer architecture and organisation - including processors, memory, storage
systems and input/output devices;
- Systems software – Operating systems and
application system software.

items.name: Data & Information Management
items.description:
An understanding is required of how data
is captured, represented, organised and
retrieved from files and databases. Topics
include:

- Data modelling and abstraction
- Database Management Systems (DBMS)
- Information assurance and security in a
shared environment
- Acquisition, custodianship and eventual
disposition of information
- Nature of data, information and knowledge
transformation through technologies.

items.name: Networking
items.description:
This area requires an understanding of
data communications and networking
fundamentals. Topics include:

- Network concepts, protocols and standards
- Network security
- Wireless and mobile computing
- Distributed systems.

items.name: Programming
items.description:
This involves an understanding of the
fundamental concepts of a programming
language. It is expected that the requisite
knowledge of programming fundamentals
would be best developed by engaging
students in software developments tasks
(programming). However, the range of
programming languages and tools that could
be used to develop this knowledge is wide
and will vary with the expected ICT job role of
the graduate.

items.name: Human Factors
items.description:
This area requires an understanding of the
importance of the user in developing ICT
applications and systems, and involves
developing a mindset that recognises the
importance of users, their work practices and
organisational contexts.

items.name: Systems Development
items.description:
An understanding is required of how to
develop or acquire software (information)
systems that satisfy the requirements of
users and customers. All phases of the
lifecycle of an information system should
be understood including: requirement
analysis (systems analysis) and specification,
design, construction, testing, and operation
and maintenance. There should also be
knowledge of methodologies and processes
for developing systems.

items.name: Systems Acquisition
items.description:
An understanding is required of how to
develop or acquire software (information)
systems that satisfy the requirements of
users and customers. All phases of the
lifecycle of an information system should
be understood including: requirement
analysis (systems analysis) and specification,
design, construction, testing, and operation
and maintenance. There should also be
knowledge of methodologies and processes
for developing systems.

items.name: IT Governance & Organisational Issues
items.description:
Topics covered should include:

- Fundamental governance principles (e.g.
structures to encourage moral behaviour
within organisations and corporations,
and moral behaviour by organisations and
corporations);
- Organisational context, including business
processes, organisational culture, change
and risk management.

items.name: IT Project Management
items.description:
This area involves an understanding
of the factors required to successfully
manage systems development projects.
Topics include: team management,
estimation techniques, cost/benefit
analysis, risk analysis, risk management,
project scheduling, quality assurance,
software configuration management,
project management tools, reporting and
presentation techniques.

items.name: Service Management
items.description:
Service management deals with the ongoing
operation of ICT in an organisational context
and includes frameworks for structuring
the interactions of ICT technical personnel
with business customers and users. Many
frameworks exist to guide ICT service
management, for example, the Information
Technology Infrastructure Library (ITIL)
and Control Objectives for Information and
Related Technology (COBIT).

items.name: Security Management
items.description:
Topics covered should include:

- Computer system security: CPU,
Peripherals, OS. This includes data security.
- Physical security: The premises occupied
by the ICT personnel and equipment.
- Operational security: Environment control,
power equipment, operation activities.
- Procedural security: By IT, vendor,
management personnel, as well as
ordinary users.
- Communications security:
Communications equipment, personnel,
transmission paths, and adjacent areas.
